articleContent.title: Chord: 9th in D# (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: 9th in D# (Shape: E)

## Brief Presentation:

The 9th chord in the key of D# (enharmonically the same as an Eb) is based on the E shape. This chord is often used in various genres of music to add color and tension to progressions. In the key of D#, the 9th chord consists of the notes D#, G, A#, D, and F.

## Notes & Intervals:

- D# (Root)
- G (Major 3rd)
- A# (Perfect 5th)
- D (Root an octave higher)
- F (Major 7th)

The chord structure can be broken down as follows: 
- Root (D#)
- Major 3rd (G)
- Perfect 5th (A#)
- Root an octave higher (D)
- Major 7th (F)

## Genre and Musical Flavor:

The 9th chord in D# is commonly used in Jazz, R&B, Funk, and Soul genres to create a rich, jazzy sound. It adds a sense of sophistication and depth to chord progressions, making them sound more complex and harmonically interesting. This chord has a smooth and mellow quality that can evoke both a sense of tension and resolution within a song.

## Songs:

Here are three songs that feature the 9th chord in D# (E shape):
- "So What" by Miles Davis
- "Georgia on My Mind" by Ray Charles
- "Isn't She Lovely" by Stevie Wonder
